div.p: We provide a model independent criterion which would guarantee a large flavor mixing of two quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos at the low scale, irrespective of the mixing at the high scale. We also show that such a situation is realizable for a phenomenologically interesting range of parameters of the weak scale theory. We further claim that for a similar condition to be implementable for the three generation case, the C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP parity of one of the neutrinos needs to be opposite to that of the others.

The observed atmospheric and solar neutrino anomalies from the terrestrial experiments [1, 2] seem to provide a strong evidence in favor of neutrino flavor conversions, implying that neutrinos are massive and they mix among themselves. While the details are fuzzy at this stage, it is clear that the atmospheric neutrino data require a large mixing of νμ↔ντ↔subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝜏italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:leftrightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

u_{s}) could be small, as in the small angle MSW scenario, or large, as in the large angle MSW or vacuum oscillation scenarios [2].

Since large mixing angles are involved in the possible solutions of both the anomalies, a great deal of theoretical work has gone in the understanding of the maximal mixing [4]. There are two complementary approaches: (i) searching for scenarios and symmetries beyond the standard model, and (ii) establishing general model independent criteria which guarantee the stability at the weak scale of the masses and mixing pattern that emerge at the high scale. The second approach has the advantage that it may not only narrow down the search for new physics scenarios to a manageable level, but it may also throw light on the parameters of the theory at the high scale, and on the value of the high scale itself. In this paper, we present some model independent criteria for such theories, first focussing on the two flavor case and subsequently on the three flavor models.

If neutrinos contribute even a small fraction of the dark matter [5] of the universe, the oscillation observations imply a situation where at least two neutrinos (and possibly even three) are quasi-degenerate in mass. If the neutrino mass hierarchy is inverted (m3<m1,m2subscript𝑚3subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{3}<m_{1},m_{2} where |Δ⁢m322|≫|Δ⁢m212|much-greater-thanΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑚232Δsubscriptsuperscript𝑚221VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:32 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:much-greater-than VERTBAR:| Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:||\Delta m^{2}_{32}|\gg|\Delta m^{2}_{21}|), the neutrinos ν1subscript𝜈1italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{1} and ν2subscript𝜈2italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{2} are necessarily quasi-degenerate. The study of scenarios where two or even three neutrinos are nearly degenerate is therefore of crucial importance.

The two flavor quasi-degenerate neutrino scenarios fall in two classes: the neutrino flavors in the degenerate limit can be (i) in the same C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP eigenstate or (ii) in opposite C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP eigenstates. It turns out that not only does one need to invoke different kinds of symmetries to understand the two cases, but the radiative corrections to the tree level degeneracy at the high scale can have very different implications for the two cases. For instance, it has been noted in [6, 7, 8] that in the case (ii), the radiative corrections (such as those through the RGE evolution from the seesaw to the weak scale) do not substantially affect the maximal mixing and quasi-degeneracy predicted by the theory at a high scale.

In this analysis, we point out that in the case (i), an arbitrary mixing at the high scale can get “magnified” to a large mixing, and even possibly maximal mixing, at the low scale. We find this interesting because (a) it enables a model builder to avoid any fine-tuning for the values of mixing angles at the high scale, and hence relaxes the constraints on the parameters of the high scale physics, (b) it brings a certain unity in the understanding of the quark and lepton mixings. This is arrived at by relating the radiative corrections and the degree of mass degeneracy (δ⁢mm𝛿𝑚𝑚FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end\frac{\delta m}{m}), regardless of the mixing pattern at the high scale. In the context of specific models, this also leads to relationships between the degree of degeneracy, the value of the high scale and the model parameters (e.g. tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta for the MSSM). We further extend the results to the three generation scenario and find that the constraint on Ue⁢3subscript𝑈𝑒3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} from the CHOOZ experiment [9] indicates that the C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP parity of one of the neutrinos must be opposite to that of the others for our scheme to be implementable.

Our paper is organized in the following form: in the next section, we derive our main result for the two flavor mixing. In section III, we present implications of the two flavor result for the case of the standard model and the MSSM. In section IV, we consider the extension to three generation case.

If the condition (14) is satisfied, the mixing at the scale μ𝜇italic-mu\mu tends to become maximal regardless of the value of the mixing at the scale ΛΛLambda\Lambda.

Several points are worth emphasizing here.
1. The above relation between ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon and the neutrino parameters θ𝜃italic-theta\theta, m1subscript𝑚1italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{1} and m2subscript𝑚2italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{2} is a model independent result and has profound implications for model building. For instance, it will relax the domain of parameters of the high scale theory compared to what was believed earlier for ϕ=0italic-ϕ0italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\phi=0.
2. From (14), the sign of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon must be the same as that of Δ⁢m2⁢(Λ)Δsuperscript𝑚2ΛDelta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( Lambda CLOSE:)\Delta m^{2}(\Lambda) for getting maximal mixing at the low scale. This preference is of a phenomenological importance since the sign of Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} at low scales is measured by experiments: if the solar neutrino solution is MSW, the identity of the heavier neutrino is known, and the heavy / light nature of the third neutrino may be determined through the long baseline experiments [12] or the observations of a galactic supernova [13]. The model needs to be able to reproduce this sign from the values of the masses at the high scale through the RGE. The results of this paper can thus be used to discriminate between various models for a large flavor mixing.
3. The condition (14) is not to be mistaken for a fine-tuning. Though maximal mixing at the low scale requires an exact equality (14), the condition can be slackened if we only need a large mixing. Indeed, the SK data [1] indicate |tan⁡2⁢θ¯|>22¯𝜃2VERTBAR:| TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2|\tan 2\bar{\theta}|>2 at 90% c.l.. In Fig. 1, we show the range of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon that allows a large mixing at the scale μ𝜇italic-mu\mu as a function of the mixing angle at the scale ΛΛLambda\Lambda. The region enclosed within the “leaf” gives the range of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon which generates a large mixing (|tan⁡2⁢θ¯|>22¯𝜃2VERTBAR:| TRIGFUNCTION:tangent NUMBER:2 OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-theta ARG:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:2|\tan 2\bar{\theta}|>2). From (13), changing this value would just change the scale of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon by a factor proportional to |δ⁢mm|𝛿𝑚𝑚VERTBAR:| FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start italic-m ARG:end VERTBAR:||\frac{\delta m}{m}|. The figure shows that a large mixing at the scale μ𝜇italic-mu\mu is indeed possible for a large range of neutrino parameters. The condition on the signs of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon and Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} is also relaxed if the mixing at the high scale is already large.

Let us now make a few comments on the possible extension to the case of three quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos. If mα⁢βsubscript𝑚𝛼𝛽italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\alpha\beta} are the elements of the neutrino mass matrix in the flavor basis, then in the approximation of the decoupling of the third flavor, a large mixing between flavors α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha and β𝛽italic-beta\beta is guaranteed at the low scale if

div.p: In all the models in which hτsubscriptℎ𝜏italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\tau} dominates over hesubscriptℎ𝑒italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{e} and hμsubscriptℎ𝜇italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{\mu}, we have ϵe⁢τ≈ϵμ⁢τsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑒𝜏subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇𝜏italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{e\tau}\approx\epsilon_{\mu\tau}. Then, the condition for the enhancement of Uμ⁢3subscript𝑈𝜇3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\mu 3} (21) is similar to the condition for the enhancement of Ue⁢3subscript𝑈𝑒3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} (with the replacement [μ→e,2→1]delimited-[]formulae-sequence→𝜇𝑒→21OPEN:[ italic-mu ARROW:to italic-e PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 ARROW:to NUMBER:1 CLOSE:][\mu\to e,2\to 1]) if all the neutrinos have the same C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP parity, assuming that both Uτ⁢1,Uτ⁢2≪Uτ⁢3much-less-thansubscript𝑈𝜏1subscript𝑈𝜏2subscript𝑈𝜏3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:much-less-than italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\tau 1},U_{\tau 2}\ll U_{\tau 3}. That would imply that when Uμ⁢3subscript𝑈𝜇3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{\mu 3} is magnified due to radiative corrections, so is Ue⁢3subscript𝑈𝑒3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3}. Then one cannot naturally get a small value of Ue⁢3subscript𝑈𝑒3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3} at the low scale, as is suggested by the CHOOZ data [9]. Thus, in the three generation case with quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos, we need the C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP phase of one neutrino opposite to that of the other two in order for our condition to be implementable. It should be noted that satisfying this condition still does not guarantee the stability of small Ue⁢3subscript𝑈𝑒3italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endU_{e3}.

In conclusion, we have derived a model independent condition that guarantees a large mixing at the low scale irrespective of the mixing angle at the high scale, for two quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos with the same C⁢P𝐶𝑃italic-C italic-PCP parity. The condition relates the masses at the high scale to the radiative corrections. In the case of SM and MSSM, this predicts the sign of the mass difference between the neutrinos and also gives a range for its magnitude. In MSSM, it translates into a relation between the value of the high scale ΛΛLambda\Lambda, tan⁡β𝛽TRIGFUNCTION:tangent italic-beta\tan\beta, and the common mass of the neutrinos. Extending the argument to three quasi-degenerate Majorana neutrinos, we again show in a model independent way that the CP parity of one of the neutrinos should be opposite to that of the others for our conditions to be implementable at the phenomenological level.
